reviewText: ALPHA VIDEO is a provider of vintage programming that's often unavailable elsewhere. Alpha's prices are fair, but so is transfer quality of some of their offerings. None have undergone restoration, yet the relative obscurity of their titles, plus a reasonable cost make these a worthwhile purchase..THE NAVY WAY (1944) is an indie WWII film that was distributed by PARAMOUNT.It stars Robert Lowery, Jean Parker, William Henry, Roscoe Karns and Robert Armstrong.Also with Tom Keene, John 'Skins' Miller and Joseph Crehan.Sarah Padden and former western 'B' movie star Tom Tyler are among the uncrediteds.The most cinematically original part of this film comes early on.All the inductees are given cardboard boxes with pasted-on shipping labels. The camera pans from left to right, stopping at each actor then zooming in on his handwritten label. This signals a flashback sequence that gives us some background on that character, information that helps to explain what later occurs to each man as he tries to make the grade.Also revealing is that Navy boot camp entails training similar to the Army and Marines. Besides calisthenics and obstacle course drills, enlistees learn precision marching with rifles and use these weapons on the firing range or for bayonet practice.ACTOR TRIVIAAlthough a longtime member of WARNER's stock company, Robert Armstrong is best known for RKO'sKING KONG(1933).Montana-born Jean Parker (nee Lois Mae Green) was granddaughter of a pioneer woman who had 18 children.Robert Lowery's ring skills here came from his being a boxer, also a semi-pro baseballer and football player.William Henry was a child actor, then a second unit film star. He was in twelve of John Ford's pictures.Roscoe Karns and 'Skins' Miller were both 53 when they played naval enlistees here.Stocky, short Joseph Crehan, a Broadway actor in the 'Teens, portrayed Ulysses S. Grant nine times.By 1944, Tom Tyler's rheumatoid arthritis was so disabling he could only make occasional cameo fim appearances.Cowboy star Tom Keene, a favorite of director Ed Wood, was in Ed'sPLAN 9 FROM OUTER SPACE(1959).This cult classic was Keene's final motion picture, and for many it's the one he's best remembered for.
summary: "Filmed at Great Lakes Naval Training Station...with 70,000 of Uncle Sam's fighting Bluejackets..."
Title: N/A

reviewText: ....Period piece lost to history by now...not a bad production by Pine-Thomas film/makers in co-features a one hour movie before main feature was shown on Saturday's....good looking Robert Lowery does NOT get the top/main billing as colleague Bill Henry gets the nod...he's OK too but never made another impression once the big shots came home from WW2 later...like I said, a rather well done showing the Navy's huge processing center at the Great Lakes Training Center...usual plot...boy likes girl...girl likes boy...then girl jilts him for his wealthy sailor/buddy...not much on laffs but the main theme...THE NAVY WAY...is driven home as boots undergo a nautical crash course on the way into the world's greatest Fleet...for that one reason this movie is a mini-classic for WW2 buffs...Lowery had better parts previous to this movie but he also got lost in the wake of the movie super stars who marched off from Hollywood to come home and took over their grasp where they left off...Henry and Lowery were not the only ones cast aside...as long as the war lasted they had their whirl as heart throbs long forgotten...that's life on the homefront for 4-F-ers then [ 1944]...even Roscoe Karns' role is below his usual standard as a comic relief...the DVD transfer is sort of shadowy dark and volume is low in places, too...Semper Fi....SSGT CHRIS SARNO-USMC FMF
Title: N/A

reviewText: Johnny Jersey comes from a tough neighborhood where defying authority is his only rule.  As he goes through recruit training, he just doesn't get on board. A man with a big chip on his shoulders and how he deals with authority.  A real great navy classic you cannot miss.  Very entertaining and funny at times. This DVD starring Robert Lowery, Robert Armstrong, Jean Parker, Bill Henry and Roscoe Karns.  Directed by William Berke is a 1944 B&W film lasting 75 min.
Title: N/A

reviewText: The Navy Way is a good WWII patriotic film, although the picture quality is not that great.  Originally released by Paramount, this is a re-issue by Metropolis Pictures.  All references to Paramount have been removed from the opening titles and the end title has been replaced.  The film itself is typical Alpha, which is at times too dark/too light, with a couple of minor splices.  The film is complete.  No Alpha logo.
Title: N/A

reviewText: I retired from the US Navy some time back after a little over 24 years of service. So many of the Boot Camp scenes were very familiar to me. The movie was like a walk down memory lane. Things have change since then but the pride, the honor and the commitment remains the same. It all starts in Boot Camp! I encourage anybody who wants to know what their uncle did when he first enlisted in the US Navy and went to Boot Camp to see this movie! Some of the characters in the movie I recall from my days in Boot Camp. Then the day all Boots look forward to, yes getting orders to the fleet. A good ship reflects the great men and women that serve on her.So enjoy the movie. Have a great Navy Day!
